word.definition: face up to and deal with (a problem or difficult situation).
word.example: He confronted his fears by trapping the spider under a bowl.

word.definition: to move, rush, dash, or surge furiously.
word.example: The river raged down the slope at a blistering pace.

word.definition: to cause mirth, laughter, or the like
word.example: The comedian amused the audience with a steady stream of jokes.

word.definition: to turn away or aside
word.example: Feeling guilty the lawyer decided to avert his gaze from the judge.

word.definition: to place close together or side by side, especially for comparison or contrast
word.example: The artist decided to juxtapose his newest creations to compare them.

word.definition: to find the answer or explanation for; clear up;explain
word.example: The student asked the professor for some help to solve the homework problem

word.definition: incapable of being surmounted, passed over, or overcome, insuperable
word.example: The hiker always thought that Mount Everest was an insurmountable mountain.

word.definition: lacking sense, significance, or ideas;silly
word.example: The father was slowly growing tired of all the inane questions his child kept asking him.

word.definition: of very little importance or value; insignificant
word.example: The politician told his aide not to bother him with any more trivial matters.

word.definition: of, relating to , or produced by a trauma or wound
word.example: The lone soldier didn't want to talk about his traumatic experiences in the war, becuase it pained him too much.

word.definition: incapable of being expressed or described in words; inexpressible
word.example: After getting into her dream college she was unable to contain her ineffiable joy.

word.definition: to walk, especially laboriously or wearily
word.example: The rather chubby man while working out decided to trudge up the long flight of steps for more exercise.

word.definition: to proceed by or take a winding or indirect course
word.example: The stream meandered through the valley

word.definition: to make or force(one's way) gradually by moving sideways
word.example: The shopper decided to edge her way through the shopping crowd.

word.definition: to go at a slow, easy pace; stroll;saunter
word.example: He ambled around the town

word.definition: the language, especially the vocabulary peculiar to a particular trade, profession, or group.
word.example: The scientist decided that he couldn't understand all the medical jargon the doctors were using.

word.definition: something that deserves or justices a reward or commendation ; a commendable quality, act,etc..
word.example: The book's only merit is its sincerity.

word.definition: absence or deprivation of advantage or equality
word.example: With blood all over his face the boxer was at a disadvantage.

word.definition: something given or received in return or recompensation for service, merit, hardship, etc.
word.example: The king bestowed the reward of knighthood upon his trusted general.

word.definition: any question or matter involving doubt, uncertainty, or difficulty
word.example: The problem of the riots was troubling the president greatly.

word.definition: inclined to silence; reserved in speech; reluctant to join in conversation
word.example: Everyone didn't like Jack's taciturn nature, because it made it hard to keep up a conversation with him.

word.definition: fond of the company of others; sociable
word.example: Jacky was a very gregarious person. She kept hosting parties every weekend and invited everyone.

word.definition: excessively talkative in a rambling, roundabout manner, epecially about trivial matters
word.example: Rachel always thought that Mindy's garruolous talk about her dog was boring.

word.definition: allowing the possibilty of several different meanings, as a word or phrase, especially with intent to deceive or misguide; susceptible of double interpretation; deliberately ambiguous
word.example: Jack's equivocal answer to the confession made Emily so confused.

word.definition: making claims or pretensions of superior importance or rights ; overbearingly assuming; insolently proud
word.example: The arrogant public official wouldn't stop claiming how he was the only one fit to lead the people.

word.definition: abounding or swarming with something, as with people
word.example: The house was teeming with hornets.

word.definition: not possessing , untouched by, void, or destitute
word.example: Detroit after being filled with people for so many years is now devoid of people.

word.definition: to reduce(an object) to useless fragments, a useless form , or remains, as by rending, burning, or dissolving; injure beyond repair or renewal; demolish; ruin; annihilate.
word.example: The city Detroit was destroyed by the local gangs residing there.

word.definition: to bring into a more desirable or excellent condition
word.example: The office atmosphere was improved by the flowers.

word.definition: causing activity or change; capable of exerting influence
word.example: Unable to withstand the unjust government Jacob decided to commit active treason.

word.definition: to give encouragement or support to (a person, plan, etc..)
word.example: Jack decided to buttress the plan about world domination.

word.definition: to find out definitely; learn with certainty or assurance ; determine:
word.example: The judge needed to ascertain the facts before making his judgement

word.definition: to engage in argument or debate
word.example: Johnny decided to dispute with his friend about whether it was pronounced katsup or ketchup.

word.definition: to prove false or erroneous, as an opinion or change
word.example: Sami began to refute Donald Trump's proposition about creating a wall against Mexico.

word.definition: to free from guilt or blame or their consequences
word.example: The court absolved her of guilt in his death

word.definition: reckless boldness; rashness
word.example: In a fit of temerity Leroy charged into the enemies.

word.definition: quality or state of being wise; knowledge of what is true or right coupled with just judgement as to action; sagacity, discernment, or insight
word.example: Wisdom is the knowledge that tomato doesn't belong in a fruit salad.

word.definition: the feeling of a person whose attention , concern, or curiosity is particularly engaged by something
word.example: She has a great interest in the poetry of Donne.

word.definition: tremulous fear, alarm, or agitation; perturbation
word.example: Jacky was in a constant state of trepidation after killing her father.

word.definition: an act or instance of condescending
word.example: On succeeding to the throne in September 1824 the dignity of his address and his affable condescension won him a passing popularity.

word.definition: quality or state of being wise; knowledge of what is true or right coupled with just judgement as to action; sagacity, discernment, or insight
word.example: Wisdom is the knowledge that tomato doesn't belong in a fruit salad.

word.definition: exhibiting or affected with atrophy; wasted; withered; shriveled
word.example: After starving for a month the begger has an atrophied body.

word.definition: drawn together; reduced in compass or size; made smaller ; shrunken
word.example: The redneck had a rather contracted view about gay marriage.

word.definition: extended ; lengthened
word.example: The giraffe had a rather elongated neck

word.definition: to give vigor to; fill with life and energy; energize
word.example: Giving pikachu the battery invigorated pikachu and let pikachu have an extra attack.

word.definition: to become smaller and smaller;shrink ; waste away
word.example: His vast fortune has dwindled away

word.definition: any person or animal that is generally despised or avoided
word.example: The ugly duckingling didn't like his peers treating him like a pariah.

word.definition: person who leads an austerely simple life, especially one who abstains from the normal pleasures of life or denies himself or herself material satisfaction
word.example: Living like an ascetic in the woods the lumberjack was happy.

word.definition: a beginner in learning anything; novice
word.example: A tyro at swimming Jacky almost drowned numerous times.

word.definition: a person , especially a child or a young person, having extraordinary talent or ability.
word.example: Since he was a child Kevin was a prodigy at the piano.

word.definition: a person who spends, or has spent , his or her money or substance with wasteful extravagance ; spendthrift
word.example: Everyone knew Paris Hilton was a rather prodigal person.

word.definition: to misrepresent
word.example: The newspaper belied the facts.

word.definition: made certain as to truth , accuracy , validity, availability, etc..
word.example: Confirmed reports of new fighting at the front.

word.definition: to render or declare legally void or inoperative
word.example: The lawyer wanted to nullify the contract.

word.definition: to carry out, or bring to realization, as a prophecy or promise
word.example: To fulfill the prophecy Hecules lead his army to win the battle.

word.definition: to confirm by expressing consent , approval , or formal sanction
word.example: George wanted to ratify a new constitutional ammendment.

word.definition: easily provoked to anger; very irritable
word.example: The irascible old man threw chairs at people who walked on his lawn.

word.definition: characterized by a ready and continuous flow of words;fluent;glib;talkative;
word.example: Mark was a voluble spokesman for the cause.

word.definition: quiet; inhibited; repressed; controlled:
word.example: After the argument he was much more subdued.

word.definition: filled with a sense of guilt and the desire for atonement; penitent:
word.example: Jimmy jones was not an acontrite sinner.

word.definition: teaching or intending to teach a moral lesson.
word.example: The english teacher has made the students read a didactic poem about love.

word.definition: tending to conciliate
word.example: Jacky was talking in a rather conciliatory manner.

word.definition: producing in large quantities or with great frequencies; highly productive
word.example: James Patterson was a rather prolific writer.

word.definition: attacking or ignoring cherished beliefs and long-held traditions, etc., as being based on error , superstition , or lack of creativity.
word.example: An iconoclastic architect whose buildings are like monumental sculptures.

word.definition: stubbornly perverse or rebellious; willfully and obstinately disobedient
word.example: Romeo had a rather contumacious personality being rebellious at any given moment.

word.definition: a feeling of irritation or resentment, as from a wound to pride or self-esteem
word.example: After losing his tail the dog was in a pique.

word.definition: sincere penitence or remorse
word.example: After his parents died Batman was in a contrition state.

word.definition: cheerful acquiescence or consent
word.example: Marky Mark was always in a state of goodwill.

word.definition: the character ,qualities, practices, etc. , of a pedant, especially undue display of learning
word.example: As a man thirsting for knowledge finding another man who was also a pedantry was exciting.

word.definition: caution with regard to practical matters
word.example: The spy was approaching the base with great prudence

word.definition: to feel or express sorrow or regret for
word.example: Charizard was lamenting over the loss of his trainer.

word.definition: the act of a person who rejoices
word.example: Charmander had a rejoicing after he won the battle.

word.definition: To state or assert positively; maintain as true
word.example: The soldier had to affirm his loyalty to the crown.

word.definition: to make remarks, observations, or criticisms
word.example: He refused to comment on the decision of the court.

word.definition: to refer briefly to; name, specify, or speak of;
word.example: Don't forget to mention her contributions to the project.

word.definition: contrary or opposed in character; discordant
word.example: The artist realized he was using incompatible colors.

word.definition: having the same ancestry or descent
word.example: Mark realize his friend and him were connected by a consanguineous family treeline.

word.definition: capable of being discerned; distinguisable
word.example: After ten minutes the man realize the discernible differences between the twins.

word.definition: to discover the meaning of(anything obscure or difficult to trace or understand)
word.example: The archaeologist tried to decipher the hieroglyphics.

word.definition: agreeing or accordant;compatible; not self-contradictory
word.example: The trainer's views and actions are consistent.

word.definition: to throw off(something) as an obstacle or burden; discard
word.example: The captain decided to jettison the lifeboats off the ship.

word.definition: to turn bottom up;overturn
word.example: Millhouse capsized the boat.

word.definition: to save from shipwreck,fire , etc
word.example: The camper salvaged the remains of his book from the fire.

word.definition: to make larger;enlarge in size, number , strength , or extent ; increase;
word.example: His salary is augmented by a small inheritance.

word.definition: to mention separately as if in counting; name one by one;specify, as in a list
word.example: Let me enumerate the many flaws in your hypothesis

word.definition: pertaining to or containing an anachronism
word.example: The trainer had such an anachronistic view about swords in modern warfare.

word.definition: deliberate breach of faith or trust; faithless;treachery
word.example: Italy's perfidy will not go unpunished.

word.definition: brutally harsh; vitriolic ;scathing
word.example: His truculent criticism of her work made her cry.

word.definition: an aptitude for making desirable discoveries by accident
word.example: The serendipity of getting the first job she applied for.

word.definition: character or conduct that emphasizes practicality
word.example: The pragmatism of the instructor saved the group from dying in the wild multiple times.

word.definition: the faculty of discerning;discrimination;acuteness of judgement and understanding
word.example: Her ability of discernment let the detective solve many cases.

word.definition: monotonously or annoying protracted or continued; unceasing;incessant
word.example: I can't stand that interminable chatter

word.definition: not intelligible; not capable of being understood
word.example: The baby talking was unintelligble.

word.definition: of little or no importance; insignificant;trivial
word.example: The opponents arguments were inconsequential to the crime at hand.

word.definition: not plausible; not having the appearance of truth or credibility
word.example: The butler's alibi of picking up the mail on Sunday was implausible.

word.definition: vanishing;fading away;fleeting
word.example: The moon's phases were a slow evanescent of sunlight.
